name: (1E)-1-(1,2-dihydroacenaphthylen-5-yl)-N-hydroxy-2-phenylethanimine
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-896

name: (1E)-1-(1,2-dihydroacenaphthylen-5-yl)-N-hydroxy-2-phenylethanimine
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-896
Reason: The basic unit acenaphthene has a melting point of 93 °C. This compound includes a hydroxylamine (-NHOH), a benzene ring, and an ethanimine group (C=C-C=N) attached to the acenaphthene structure. The hydroxylamine group would be expected to increase the melting point due to hydrogen bonding capability, which might increase the melting point by approximately 30 °C. The additional benzene ring could contribute an extra 20 °C by increasing the molecular complexity and planarity, enhancing π-π interactions. The ethanimine group may also contribute by adding rigidity and potential for dipole-dipole interactions, estimated to increase the melting point by about 10 °C.

name: (1E)-1-(1,2-dihydroacenaphthylen-5-yl)-N-hydroxy-2-phenylethanimine
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-896
Reason: The basic unit acenaphthene has a melting point of 93 °C. Adding the hydroxylamine group to the structure is expected to raise the melting point significantly due to the possibility of intermolecular hydrogen bonding. This hydrogen bonding capability is estimated to contribute an increase of around 45 °C. Incorporation of the phenyl group, being a large planar aromatic system, will also increase the melting point through enhanced π-π stacking interactions with other molecules. This could contribute an additional 20 °C. The ethanimine side chain contributes further by introducing steric hindrance and a possible rigidification of the structure, contributing around 10 °C. Therefore, the sum of the additional increments based on functional group effects should be approximately equal to 75 °C, resulting in a prediction closely matching the actual value.

name: (1E)-1-(1,2-dihydroacenaphthylen-5-yl)-N-hydroxy-2-phenylethanimine
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-896
Reason: The target compound contains multiple functional groups and structural features that influence its melting point. - Basic unit, benzene has a melting point of 5.5 °C. - Phenyl group: +30 °C for each, due to the increment in molecular weight and the planar structure, contributing to increased van der Waals interactions. Since there are two phenyl groups, this results in an addition of +60 °C. - N-hydroxyethanimine moiety: +40 °C, due to hydrogen bonding capability of the hydroxyl and imine groups, and the polar nature of the overall moiety, which enhances intermolecular interactions. - Acenaphthylene framework: +25 °C, due to the rigid bicyclic structure that provides additional planar surfaces for stacking, increasing the van der Waals interactions. - Double bond: +5 °C, because it creates a rigid planar area that can stack well with other molecules, increasing the melting point slightly. Considering all these increments: 5.5 (basic benzene unit) + 60 (phenyl groups) + 40 (N-hydroxyethanimine) + 25 (acenaphthylene framework) + 5 (double bond), we can predict the melting point.
